label: lecture 9 Greedy Algorithms.pdf
title: Greedy Algorithms and Activity Selection & Knapsack Problems (Fractional and 0-1)

questions.text: What is the core principle behind the design of a Greedy Algorithm?

choices.label: It makes a choice that looks best at the moment (locally optimal) to hopefully find a global optimum.
choices.text: It makes a choice that looks best at the moment (locally optimal) to hopefully find a global optimum.

choices.label: It breaks the problem into subproblems and solves them from smallest to largest.
choices.text: It breaks the problem into subproblems and solves them from smallest to largest.

choices.label: It systematically explores all possible solutions to guarantee the best result.
choices.text: It systematically explores all possible solutions to guarantee the best result.

choices.label: It uses a random selection process to avoid getting stuck in local optima.
choices.text: It uses a random selection process to avoid getting stuck in local optima.

questions.explanation: According to the text, a greedy algorithm makes a locally optimal choice in the hope of getting a globally optimal solution.

questions.text: How does the text compare the problem-solving direction of Greedy Algorithms versus Dynamic Programming?

choices.label: Greedy algorithms are typically top-down, while Dynamic Programming is bottom-up.
choices.text: Greedy algorithms are typically top-down, while Dynamic Programming is bottom-up.

choices.label: Greedy algorithms are bottom-up, while Dynamic Programming is top-down.
choices.text: Greedy algorithms are bottom-up, while Dynamic Programming is top-down.

questions.explanation: The text states that Dynamic Programming is a bottom-up solution (from smaller to larger subproblems), while Greedy algorithms are top-down (make a choice and then solve the subproblem).

questions.text: In the Activity Selection Problem, what is the specific greedy choice that guarantees an optimal solution?

choices.label: Select the activity with the earliest start time.
choices.text: Select the activity with the earliest start time.

choices.label: Select the activity with the shortest duration.
choices.text: Select the activity with the shortest duration.

choices.label: Select the activity with the earliest finish time.
choices.text: Select the activity with the earliest finish time.

choices.label: Select the activity that overlaps with the fewest other activities.
choices.text: Select the activity that overlaps with the fewest other activities.

questions.explanation: The greedy approach described selects the activity \(a_m\) with the earliest finish time to maximize the unscheduled time remaining.

questions.text: For the Activity Selection Problem, if the activities are already sorted by finish time, what is the running time of the algorithm?
questions.explanation: The text states that the `GREEDY-ACTIVITY-SELECTOR` assumes activities are ordered and has a running time of \(\Theta(n)\) because each activity is examined only once.

questions.text: What property allows the Activity Selection Problem to be solved without solving all subproblems first?
questions.explanation: The Greedy Choice Property ensures that by making the locally optimal choice (earliest finish time), we are guaranteed to use an activity included in an optimal solution, thus avoiding the need to solve the subproblem before making the choice.

questions.text: Which metric is used to greedily select items for the Fractional Knapsack Problem to ensure an optimal solution?
questions.explanation: The greedy strategy for the Fractional Knapsack Problem is to pick the item with the maximum value per pound (\(v_i/w_i\)).

questions.text: What is the time complexity of the Fractional Knapsack algorithm if the items are **not** initially ordered by their value-to-weight ratio?
questions.explanation: The text notes that the running time is \(\Theta(n)\) if items are already ordered; else it is \(\Theta(n \lg n)\) due to the sorting requirement.

questions.text: Why does the greedy strategy fail for the 0-1 Knapsack Problem?

choices.label: The greedy choice property does not hold because items cannot be divided.
choices.text: The greedy choice property does not hold because items cannot be divided.

choices.label: The problem size is too large for greedy algorithms.
choices.text: The problem size is too large for greedy algorithms.

choices.label: The values and weights are not integers.
choices.text: The values and weights are not integers.

choices.label: There is no way to sort the items.
choices.text: There is no way to sort the items.

questions.explanation: The text demonstrates with an example that locally optimal greedy choices (like taking the highest value item or highest ratio) do not necessarily lead to a global optimal solution because items must be taken entirely or left behind.

questions.text: In the Dynamic Programming solution for the 0-1 Knapsack Problem, what does \(P(i, w)\) represent?

choices.label: The weight of the knapsack using items 1 to \(i\).
choices.text: The weight of the knapsack using items 1 to \(i\).

choices.label: The maximum profit obtainable from items 1 to \(i\) with knapsack capacity \(w\).
choices.text: The maximum profit obtainable from items 1 to \(i\) with knapsack capacity \(w\).

choices.label: The ratio of value to weight for item \(i\).
choices.text: The ratio of value to weight for item \(i\).

choices.label: The minimum space remaining in the knapsack.
choices.text: The minimum space remaining in the knapsack.

questions.explanation: The text defines \(P(i, w)\) as the maximum profit that can be obtained from items 1 to \(i\), if the knapsack has size \(w\).

questions.text: Which recurrence relation describes the 0-1 Knapsack Problem using Dynamic Programming?
questions.explanation: The recurrence relation given is \( P(i, w) = \max \{ v_i + P(i-1, w-w_i), P(i-1, w) \} \), representing the choice between taking item \(i\) or not taking it.
